Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge erred in denying citizenship based on residency and procedural fairness
Application_Facts: Applicants were denied citizenship due to insufficient physical presence in Canada; they were abroad during part of the required period
Court_Ruling: Matter remitted for rehearing before a different citizenship judge
Defendant_Behavior: Citizenship judge failed to review submitted questionnaires and did not provide a fair hearing
Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of fair opportunity to present case, failure to assess residency properly
Legal_Standard: Section 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act – residency requirement; Section 14(5) – right to appeal
Assessment_Factor: Physical presence in Canada over the required period
Procedural_Issue: Denial of procedural fairness in the assessment process
Review_Standard: Reasonableness and compliance with procedural fairness
Legal_Provision_Cited: Section 5(1)(c), Section 14(5) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Basis: Failure to meet minimum physical presence requirement for citizenship
Evidence_Assessed: Residency questionnaires (not reviewed by the judge)
Relief_Sought: Allow appeal and remit for reconsideration
Governing_Rule: Section 5(1)(c): applicant must be physically present in Canada for specified period
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Judge did not review key documents (residency questionnaires)
Harm_Assessment: Applicants denied fair hearing affecting citizenship rights
Cause_Description: Applicants did not meet residency requirement, and the judge failed to provide a fair hearing process
Evidence_Handling: Failure to consider submitted residency documentation
Evidence_Issues: Key evidence not reviewed by decision maker
Evidence_Assessment: Inadequate – judge did not assess submitted questionnaires
Decision_Rationale: Procedural unfairness and incorrect application of residency rules
Decision_Making_Body: Citizenship judge, Federal Court Trial Division
Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness and statutory residency requirements
